utterances: Maybe she should have talked to Lawrence Welk.
Mr.
McCRACKEN: Yeah.
And one thing that the ""PPGZ"" program is, once we did the initial development on it, I kind of gave them my blessing and said, you know, you guys can go off and this show.
So, I'm not really involved in the daily production of that show and supervising things, and kind of giving my comments on it.
I was really just there in the initial conception of it.
Mm-hmm.
And one of the ideas was if you wanted to make it fly in Asia, you better turn this creative end of it over to Asians.
Mr.
McCRACKEN: Yeah.

And one big issue that we did deal with with the show is when they first pitched their concept, the character of Professor Utonium wasn't in it and they just had, you know, those three girls, you know, off fighting crime.
And I said, well, they really need a father figure, they really need someone to look after them.
And it didn't - and they thought it was weird.
They said, wasn't it strange that there's a single father with three daughters?
Mm-hmm.
Mr.

McCRACKEN: And they didn't realize it was a cultural thing in Asia, where the idea of a single father who, possibly, you know, has been divorced or, you know, whose wife is passed away, that typically in those situations, a husband would remarry or, you know, the children would go with the mother.
And so, they were, you know, really resistant to having him be their actual biological father.
But I said, they at least need a father figure in the show.
So, is he now back in the show in some other slightly different capacity?
Mr.
McCRACKEN: Yeah.
He is back in the show as just, kind of parental figure.
Uh-huh.
All right.
I guess they didn't see ""Charlie's Angels"" too much, either.
Mr.
McCRACKEN: Right, right.
Okay.
Thanks very much for the call, Michael.
This is...
Mr.
McCRACKEN: Yeah, I don't know either.
I mean, like I - one thing we did try to stress with the producers is that we want to try to keep ""PPGZ"" as a kids show.
There's a lot of anime that's produced that's very much for adults, and we understand that there's a market for that.
But we wanted to make sure that ""PPGZ"" was still predominantly for kids.
And I really was unfamiliar with the champagne attack.
Like I said, you know, I had kind of just been involved, peripherally, in the beginning of the show.
Hmm.
Thanks for the call, Michael.
Here's an e-mail.
This from Tom(ph) in Winston-Salem, North Carolina.
I retired from the U.S.
Department of State after 25 years and lived overseas most of my life.
Excluding some fundamentalist Muslim countries, the USA is the most sexually-conservative country in the world.
No surprise ""The Powerpuff Girls"" are more muted here than almost anywhere else.
I wonder, Amy Chozick, what do you think about that?
Well, it's interesting.
You know, some readers responded that it's too bad ""The Powerpuff Girls"" look like Barbies in Japan.
Mm-hmm.

But I think that just plays into the kind of the taste for animation there and also, the appeal that it has towards grown men or a joke Craig was speaking about, Otaku in Japan - also called geeks - are very into animation and they like this aesthetic of the long legs and the doe-eyed girls.
Mr. McCRACKEN: Mm-hmm.
We're talking about the transcreation - that's the term of art, transcreation of cartoon characters as they go overseas.
Our guests are Amy Chozick of the Wall Street Journal and Craig McCracken, the creator of ""The Powerpuff Girls."" If you'd like to join the conversation: 800-989-8255, e-mail us: talk@npr.org.
This is the TALK OF THE NATION coming to you from NPR News.
And let's see if we can get another caller on the line.
This Carrie(ph).
Carrie with us from Oak Park in Illinois.
Hi, how are you?
I'm good, thanks.
You know, I was riding a mini-bus one day in Beijing and there was this toddler next to me and she started saying, ye ye, ye ye, which is the word for grandfather.
Her mother said, what, what grandfather?
Who do you see?
She's pointing to Colonel Sanders outside Kentucky Fried Chicken, who they call Grandfather Kentucky, you know?
And also, Ronald McDonald over there is Uncle McDonald because, you know, you just have to have some kind of family relationship, I guess, as opposed to some random guy trying to sell you something.
Huh.
Have you noticed that, Amy Chozick?
Oh, that's interesting.
Yeah.
Colonel Sanders takes along many images in Asia.
But in terms of transcreation, I really haven't noticed that.
Hmm.
But that's interesting.
Interesting.
Carrie, sounds like you've got some young consumers of your own to take care of.
Yeah.
You know, I gave her some Cheerios, I was hoping she'd be quiet, but…

Thank you.

Terry is with us from McAlester in Oklahoma.

Hello, my name is Terry.

I was just curious to know why the change of the Looney Tunes characters, you know, here in the United States, they - we used to have the traditional forms, I guess, of cartooning and now they've changed it to this more sleek, gothic, kind of, Japanese animation.
And it's, kind of, odd that they would show it here in the United States.
And I'll take my answer off the air.
Okay.
That maybe more of an industrial question than an artistic one necessarily.
Craig McCracken, what do you think?
Mr.

McCRACKEN: I think she's referring to a program that Kids' WB produced called ""Loonatics Unleashed."" And I think that was just really just an attempt, I think, from Warner Brothers to try to breathe some new life into the Warner's characters.

I - hopefully - you know, because I'm a big fan of the classics -they weren't trying to replace them, and hopefully, it was just like an attempt to see almost like a transcreation here, just to see - will kids like them better if they're edgier and…
And move their demographic a little younger, yeah.
Mr.
McCRACKEN: Yeah.
I'm not sure what it was.
I mean, I haven't seen of anything in that show for a long time.
And, you know, just as a fan of the classics, I'm kind of happy that Bugs Bunny still has a place, you know, the comedic character that I, you know, know and love and…
Yeah.
By the way, listeners can see how the Powerpuff Girls were transformed for Japanese fans if they go to npr.org/talk.
And it's interesting, Amy Chozick, that there are some characters for whom this was either not necessary, or that it didn't work, for one reason or another.
Right.
Exactly.
Some characters just ended up, kind of, transcreating themselves.
Dora the Explorer,"" for instance, when she went to China, Chinese kids thought, oh, she looks Chinese.
She looks like me.
So, they - Nickelodeon, kind of, did away with her Hispanic heritage.
And now, she teaches English to Chinese kids.
Mm-hmm.
Yeah.
We're putting it in digitally.
We're doing a digital effect.
We're going to put the ball in, going straight towards camera, and then coming down into his arms.
You could never make that happen for real.
(Soundbite of voices)
Darwin Booher is Mark Baker's state senator and is fighting the order.
And then, there's SpongeBob, who everybody said would flop in Japan, where they like round characters with tiny eyes and non-existent mouth like Hello Kitty.
And here's SpongeBob with huge eyes and a huge mouth and kind of an irritating personality.
And he's a huge hit.
Two million households tune in to watch him on Saturdays.
So, sometimes, things creep in under the radar.
And it's also some characters can't be changed including, for example, any of the ""Peanuts"" characters.
Oh, exactly.
This is serious stuff.
They - any of the Peanuts are restricted from being recreated.
And the Times of India decided that Snoopy should be brown.
So, they had been coloring Snoopy brown.
And when the Wall Street Journal inquired about this, they - United Media, which controls ""Peanuts,"" said it was a coloring error that would be fixed.
So, Snoopy is now white in the Times of India.
